content.description: Can you say thin and crimpy?  Warm up your digits before jumping on this test of finger strength and technique.  Starting just right of the tree while standing on the rock platform below, pull up onto some good feet before crimping, smearing and edging your way up and slightly left to a good flake.  A few more terrible holds and a little balance will net you the sloping top.  Topout before lowering down.
content.protection: Toprope off of the trees above.  There isn't a single gear placement on this route.
content.location: On the far left end of the slabs, this route climbs the short, ultra-thin face immediately right of a tree and roughly 15 feet to the left of the climbs Clingon and Sunday Solo.

content.description:
A very challenging slab problem... 

  Make hard moves up the starting bulge then tackle the smooth slab above... The the friction isnt the crux but it aint easy either... 

  All the hard routes om the slabs are a bit contrived the rule on theis one i belive is stay right of and good holds on the slab and left of the corner meaning dont grab the corner...
content.location: 5 feet left of The Corner/The Book (5.8)...

content.description: Pulling the mini-roof is the highlight of this climb and it utilizes a cool high foot and a couple of slopers. Then continue up the slab/dike above using a few interesting moves, but mainly just running up to the top.
content.location: Just left of the Dike Route

content.description:
A fun friction slab finish to the classic Pete's Tree.

 Climb the initial crack on Pete's tree to a stance at a triangular cutout at feet level.  Follow the shallow left leaning trough up to the left to finish near the top of the Flake Route.
content.protection: Wouldn't be much pro unless one gets some gear high on Pete's prior to the traverse left on the face.  Maybe best as a TR.
content.location: Start's on Pete's Tree but after the initial crack right leaning crack of Pete's, follow the shallow trough left from the first good horizontal feet stance.

content.description:
A fun and easier option to Pete's Tree Right.

 Climb up on nice features and fairly good feet.  Pop up into the little scoop and step up to join up with Pete's Tree Right.

 Avoids the more difficult start over the bulge.

 Leadable but no protection at the start until joining Pete's Tree Right and some thinner crack features on that route.

 Nice TR option for another short climb from a tree anchor above Pete's Tree.
content.protection: No pro pulling the bottom difficulties.  Same pro as for Pete's Tree Right when joining that route.
content.location:
Left hand variation of Pete's Tree Right.

 Just right of Pete's Tree right slanting crack.

content.description:
Not a bad climb and it doesnt see as much use as the "mega classic camper routes" so on a busy day you can still get a rope on it... 

  Start by getting up on a big detached flake/boulder leaning on the wall then climb the bulge above where the angling dike crosses it... That bulge is the 5.7 crux and once you are over that its a cruise to the top... There is an easier variation going around the bulge to the left...
content.protection: You can fiddle in a piece to the left i think then put cams in the horizontals above but most just drop the trusty TR...
content.location: Just right of the way too popular Pete's Tree...

content.description: The obvious line on this section of the cliff, the crack system between the Flake Route and The Dike.  It starts on the right-angling hand crack (a few face moves are more fun.)  Climb up to a comfortable rest with a vertical seam leading to the left-angling finger-crack system.  The crux is getting into the second crack system, but it is easily protected with a medium nut or TCU.  Find the good feet on the face and finger locks.  The route is classic except for the last 5 feet which are just a little akward.
content.protection: Small/medium nuts (up to #9 or #10) and cams up to thin hands.  I find TCUs work better on the upper section.  The route is easily toproped from trees about 5-10 feet back from the top.
content.location: On the lower slabs between the Flake Route (5.5) and The Dike (5.8). Start at the right-angling hand crack.

content.description:
This climb is a great moderate for beginners (top-rope) who want to challenge themselves and competent leaders who want to scare themselves with the runout near the bottom and towards the top. 

  Start off the ground at a small corner and a polished high foot, smear your feet up the polish with a pinch on the left arete of the corner and your right hand desperately searching for a good hold, get into a standing position and make your way up to the very small gear placement about 15 ft off the ground then make your way up easier ground and eventually a slab to the top.
content.protection: Small at the bottom and spaced at the top.
content.location: Obvious shallow, right-facing corner on right/center of cliff.

content.description:
Start just left of Beginners route, left of the tree... Pull over a small overlap to get on the the slab then crimp and smear up past a shallow arch and cross Beginners Route climbing up the slab above and a little right smear your way past three mounds (hence the name of the climb)... 

  Very good fun indeed...
content.location: Start left of Beginners Route the cross that route to the right and up the slab...

content.description: Start just left of Pete's Tree and climb straight up the difficult steep slab... Eventually you get to some holds, just crimps but at least they are holds... Then the angle eases up and if you made it through the bottom part it should be a walk to the top...a fun route for sure but it doesnt get climbed  too much....
content.location: Take a step left from Pete's Tree and climb up the blankish face...

content.description: Great route at the grade.   Beginning will be harder than 5.5 (more like 5.9) for children and very short climbers.   the rest of the route is very enjoyable and follows the flake system to its end and then ascends easy slab to anchor
content.protection: toprope   Trad lead for the very brave/crazy/bored
content.location: flake system on far west of cliff face

content.description: Follow the Dike up the cliff. this is a good route for beginners.
content.location: 10 feet or so from small buldge at obvious dike

content.description:
This chimney route is great for beginners having an issue with the slippery feet of Pawtuckaway. In my opinion this is the easiest route that Pawtuckaway has to offer. I would recommend this route for the youngsters. 

  I always wondered the name of this route and found the name on the net after my young daughter completed it. Let me know if it goes by any other name.
content.protection: Easily TR from large trees above. However, trad is an option here if your ok running it out. there is one placement from the group and one midway through the climb. after that you might be able to get a sketchy nut in but I would say your on your own for the upper section.
content.location: Located on the left side of the slabs. Easy to spot this chimney on your way to the path to the to cliff top access and upper cliff.

content.description:
Another somewhat contrived but enjoyable slab that is very good practice for hard slabs everywhere...  

  Climb the slab between The Corner (5.8) and Beginners Route (5.6) not using the holds on either of those... Smear your way up the sustained slab to the horizontal crack... Then on to the top with little difficulty...
content.location: Between Beginners Route and The Corner...

content.description:
Start on a platform of roots and dirt... Head up the smooth slab (crux) to a good flake... The climbing eases up and heads to the left to finish where the book finishes.... 

  Perhaps this was once a good beginner route but i find the beginning to be very slippery and not fun for new folks... If you have a little slab climbing under your belt its not too bad... As with most pawtuckaway routes the years of TRing have taken their toll on the friction... 

  A good lead if you are just getting in to leading trad but know how to climb pretty well... The first moves don't protect but once you get to the flake its all good gear...
content.protection: Small rack of cams and nuts... Or a top rope from big trees...

content.description: Friction climb up to a horizontal crack.  Follow the seam crack above.
content.protection: Top Rope anchors above.  Good Trees
content.location: To the right of the base of the tree where "Beginner's route" starts.  Left of the route "Little Fingers"

content.description: Collection of moderate to easy slabs topropeable for beginners. This cliff sits right on a little swampy pond so beware that when the mosquitoes are hungry you are the first thing they come after!   Bring the family as this area has a great spot to hang out at the bottom and an easy clifftop access and toprope setups off trees.
